title: Unable to use _.every in _.takeWhile
body:
I can't fathom why `_(foo).zip(bar).takeWhile(_.every)` does not work as I hoped it would. I've written [a small example](https://jsfiddle.net/4y6os404/) where I expected to see the same output twice. The example currently uses lodash 3.3.0 because of the CDN but I've verified the same behaviour on 3.5.0.

Is it the expected behaviour?

title: [Feature Request] _.guid() to create a new guid
body:
I was intrigued to find so many people using ad-hoc methods for generating guids in JavaScript 

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/105034/create-guid-uuid-in-javascript (+1300)

(myself included in copy-pasting some boilerplate from this post)  Some people even appear to be using web services to generate them.. I was also surprised to find that this has never been brought up in either the lodash project or the underscore project.

I think this feature would fit nicely under the utility functions in lodash.  What do you think?

"Since version" in docs

title: [Feature Request] object collection version of indexOf based on predicate truthiness
body: Am interested in getting the index of an object in an array based on arbitrary criteria.  This would work like find but return the integer index rather than the object.

title: Cannot merge nested json.
body: I am trying to find a method to merge 2 NESTED jsons. I tried `_.assign`,  `_.merge` and `_.defaults`. Do I have to write a recursion to loop over all the internal keys??

title: `map` over object in `chain` after `reduce`
A string formatting function?
body:
`_.template` is kinda unwieldy for tiny things, a `_.format` function would be much more helpful. I'm imagining functionality like (basing off of [how Rust does it](http://doc.rust-lang.org/std/fmt/index.html)):

``` js
var world = "world";
var helloworld = _.format("Hello {}!", world); // -> Hello world!
console.log(_.format("{} is {}!", "Lo-dash", "fun")); // Prints "Lo-dash is fun!"
```

Would be useful for getting rid of awkward string adding, like `"Hello " + name + "!"`.

title: filter + rest + map => trouble
body:
Hi, I have some problem using `filter`, `rest` and `map` in chain. After `filter` and `rest` applied `map` still can iterate over elements of the array even though there are no elements already.
Here is minimal case in interactive mode:

``` bash
> require('lodash')([1]).rest().map(function(v) { console.log(v); }).value();
[] # OK
> require('lodash')([1]).filter(function(v) { return v; }).rest().map(function(v) { console.log(v); }).value();
1 # WTF?!
[]
> 
```

I think the problem is in the lazy evaluation.

title: _.isSymbol, _.isMap, _.isSet
body: `_.isSymbol` is the biggest one here, but `_.isMap` and `_.isSet` would be easy enough to add.

title: Can yield enforce synchronization in _.each?
Make `users` not sorted by `age` to show effect
body: Now `users` are already sorted descendingly by `age`. (submitted a CLA on 2015-02-21 03:34:30)

title: _.replace(collection, match, new)
body:
Before adding the `replace` on `StringWrapper` in #1016, I thought about adding `replace`:

Replace matches in `collection` with `new`
`match` is a normal `[predicate=_.identity]`
`new` can be either:
- A value with which matched items will be replaced
- A function which takes in the old value and returns the new value.

```
_.replace(collection, match, new)

function isEven(x) { return x % 2 == 0; }
_.replace([1, 2, 3], isEven, 42)
// -> [1, 42, 3]
_.replace([1, 2, 3], isEven, function(x) { return x + 1; )
// -> [1, 3, 3]
_.replace([1, null, 3], _.isNull, 42)
// -> [1, 42, 3]
```

Why not just a `_.map`?
`_.replace([1, null, 3], _.isNull, 42)` looks really intuitive. The `isNull` can be any function you built to validate your data.

title: WIP: StringWrapper implementation for #1016
Add _.isInteger
body: This would mirror ES6 [Number.isInteger](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-number.isinteger).

title: Allow static (constant) value for _.times?
body: I just asked a [question on StackOverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/28862151/lodash-underscore-js-function-to-create-array-consisting-of-n-copies-of-x) and I realized that the number of use cases for the `_.times` method might significantly benefit from optionally accepting a static (constant) value instead of an iteratee (such that `_.times(3, 'foo');` will return `['foo', 'foo', 'foo']` ) same as using `_.times(3, _.constant('foo'));`.

title: Giving _.matches a regexp creates a function that always returns true
body:
``` javascript
var matcher = _.matches(/hi/)
matcher(/hi/) // => true
matcher("hi")  // => true
matcher(false)  // => true
matcher()  // => true
```

I'm not entirely sure what this should be doing (should it match `"hi"`, `/hi/` and `"history"`?), but this doesn't seem right.

title: Chained groupBy and forEach doesn't seem to work properly
body:
Did these symantics change in v3?

``` javascript
_([{color: 'green', name: 'foo'}, {color:'red', name:'bar'}, {color:'green', name: 'baz'}])
    .groupBy('color')
    .forEach(function(b) {
        console.log(b); // Never called
    })
```

Works in v2: https://jsfiddle.net/bg3cvrx2/

title: Add string built-ins to lodash wrapper?
body:
It's super handy that a bunch of the built-in `Array` methods (`concat`, `join`, `pop`, `push`, etc) are all added to the wrapper object. Thus when an array is wrapped, one can use any of the built-in array methods directly on the chain as if operating directly on the array.

Now that lodash has a suite of String methods, I was a bit surprised to learn that the `String` built-ins _aren't_ added to the wrapper object as well.

Was this intentional or an oversight? I would love to be able to use methods like `split` or `replace` directly on a lodash-wrapped string.

title: Does not support yield for koajs
Let `createAssigner` get correct customizer
Incosistency when going back and forth between camelCase and snakeCase
body:
When converting back and forth between camelCase and snakeCase, seems like output does not stay the same when numbers are involved. Any way to make it consistent?

```
_.snakeCase('enable24hFormat');    /* "enable_24_h_format" */
_.camelCase('enable_24_h_format'); /* "enable24HFormat" */
_.snakeCase('enable24HFormat');    /* "enable_24_hf_ormat" */
```

title: Incorrect shortcut fusion with drop and dropWhile
body:
When mixing `drop` and `dropWhile` in a lodash chain I get incorrect results (using version 3.3.1).

``` javascript
var arr = [{v:1}, {v:2}, {v:3}, {v:4}];
_(arr)
    .dropWhile('v', 1)
    .drop()
    .dropWhile('v', 3)
    .value()
// Result: [ { v: 3 }, { v: 4 } ]
// Expected: [ { v: 4 } ]
```

When I break shortcut fusion by tapping into the intermediate result before the last `dropWhile` I get the correct result:

``` javascript
_(arr)
    .dropWhile('v', 1)
    .drop()
    .tap(_.noop)
    .dropWhile('v', 3)
    .value()
// Result: [ { v: 4 } ]
```

Implement optional descending order sort in #414

The only thing I'm not sure is the jsdoc. I wrote this signature for `_.sortByAll` 's `props`:

```

```

But technically, it should be an mixed array, where element can be an Object or string.
Should I change it to this?

```

```

title: _.max always returns -Infinity when comparing strings
_.round
_.date and _.time ?
body:
Hey, I'm wondering if we could add these two methods to lodash.

```
_.date( [fullYear = false ], [delimiter = '-'] )
_.time( [showSec = true], [delimiter = ':'] )

Usage:

_.date()
-> '15-02-25'
_.date(true, '/')
-> '2015/02/25'

_.time(false)
-> '18:14'

```

What do you guys think?

title: Should _.matches(<emptything>)(<anything>) === true?
body:
Hey friends, love lodash, really great work!

I was just trying to use _.matches to do a _.reject.  However, sometimes my `source` object is undefined, and this causes the matches to always be true.  Is this by design?

I've walked the code and it looks like anything w/o any properties (E.G. empty array, empty object, undefined, null) will do this because it doesn't actually run any comparisons and instead immediately returns `true`.

If this is by design, I think there should be a note in the docs, since it is unexpected behavior to me.

Thanks!
Matt

title: _.curry() can't be used in a map
body:
I have the following code:

``` js
_(fs.readdirSync(dirPath))
  .map(_.curry(path.join, 2)(dirPath))
```

In theory, it should return the full paths of all the files in `dirPath`. Instead, it throws an error:

```
path.js:471
      throw new TypeError('Arguments to path.join must be strings');
            ^
TypeError: Arguments to path.join must be strings
    at posix.join (path.js:471:13)
    at wrapper (/Users/callumacrae/Sites/find-node-modules-down/node_modules/lodash/index.js:3165:85)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/Users/callumacrae/Sites/find-node-modules-down/index.js:9:41)
    at Module._compile (module.js:460:26)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:478:10)
    at Module.load (module.js:355:32)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:310:12)
    at Function.Module.runMain (module.js:501:10)
    at startup (node.js:129:16)
    at node.js:814:3
```

This seems to be because of the extra argument provided by `.map()`. The same error can be replicated by the following:

``` js
_.curry(path.join, 2)('one')('two', 1)
```

In my opinion, if the arity is specified, that number—and _only_ that number—of arguments should be given to the function.

``` js
_.curry(path.join, 2)('one')('two', 1) //=> path.join('one', 'two')
```

I can't think of any cases where this would break stuff, and it would be useful for currying functions for maps and stuff. Would you accept a PR fixing this functionality?

title: chaining and indexing work funny
Publish as Google Script Library

Unfortunately, [Google Scripts are strict about including libraries](https://developers.google.com/apps-script/guide_libraries) and I was only able to find a [published version of underscore](https://sites.google.com/site/scriptsexamples/custom-methods/underscoregs). Would it be possible to get an official published version of lodash available to Google Scripts?

In the worst case I can paste it in myself but I think there could be a lot of other people who would find lodash useful in this situation.

Thanks a ton for lodash!

title: No `guard` arg in _.words documentation
body:
I didn't see a separate docs repo, so I hope this is the right place to report a documentation issue.

Inspecting `_.words` on the command line, I can see it is of the form `function words(string, pattern, guard)`. However, the documentation at https://lodash.com/docs#words only lists the first two arguments, with no mention of the `guard` argument.

title: _.debounce loops indefinitely if called without “wait” argument
Chaining takeWhile and last does not work
body:
When using chaining with takeWhile and last return undefined instead of the correct value.

example:

``` javascript
    _
    .chain([1, 2, 3])
    .takeWhile(function(item) {
        return item < 3
    })
    .last()
    .value()
    // ==> undefined
```

making the same thing without chaining works correctly

``` javascript
    _.last(
        _.takeWhile([1, 2, 3], function(item) {
            return item < 3
        })
    )
    // ==> 2
```

maybe some issue with lazy evaluation?

I created a jsfiddle from this issue with the latest lodash (3.3.0)
http://jsfiddle.net/zyx2rkfa/

title: Implement descending order sort in #414.
body:
Change `compareMultipleAscending(this, other)` to
`compareMultiple(this, other, props)`, which allows sorting in descending
order for a specific property if '-' is prepended to its name.

Change sortByAll so it can sort in descending order for a specific property.
For example,`_.sortByAll(users, ['user', '-age'])` sort in ascending
order for 'user' but in descending order for 'age'.

title: Docs request: Link from docs to npm module on npmjs.com
body: It's awesome that lodash is modularized so we can require individual lodash functions here and there. However, npmjs' registry search is... lacking. (the modularized filter is linked from lodash homepage to: https://www.npmjs.com/browse/keyword/lodash-modularized. But one cannot simply search within that result set because npm's search box doesn't pre-populate so attempting to refine the search results in an npm-wide search, not lodash-specific.) Generally we know which modules we want to pull in, so finding them in the lodash docs is easiest. So a simple link right next to the source/TOC links would be perfect. Thoughts on a unicode glyph that could concisely represent the module's page on the npmjs registry?

title: improper flatten implementation
body:
Looks like the `_.flatten` definition is backward from Underscore.
http://underscorejs.org/#flatten

The change that introduced the 'deep' feature also changed the behavior of _.flatten(vals) to be _NOT_ deep.  This breaks upgrade compatibility as previous versions of lodash (we're on 2.4.1) have were deep by default.

title: _.remove by index
body:
e.g. `_.remove( arr, 999 )` to remove one specific element by its idx. Looking at docs, `number` datatype as `predicate` is still available, so why not to allow it? Can be useful for large arrays if you already know the idx in advance.

EDIT: in fact, you could implement similar logic to Resig's [JavaScript Array Remove](http://ejohn.org/blog/javascript-array-remove/) to allow for slice-like behavior for removing array elements (e.g. supplying `-1` to remove last element).

title: Merge is broken
Implicit chaining functions not consistent
body:
Could you explain why `_({x: 1}).has('x')` works fine, but `var y = _({x: 1}).has; y('x')` throws a TypeError?

Ultimately, I was hoping to be able to use code like this:

``` js
_.every(types, _(validTypes).has)
```

rather than

``` js
_.every(types, function (type) {return _.has(validTypes, type)})
```

title: Regexp predicates?
body:
I'm porting a script from (bash to) Perl to JavaScript, part of which uses lodash's `partition` function.

It's straightforward in Perl:
### Perl

``` perl
my ($options, $dirs) = partition { /^-/ ? 0 : 1 } @ARGV;
```

It's pretty verbose in ES5:
### ES5

```
var parts = _.partition(process.argv.slice(2), function (arg) { return /^-/.test(arg) })
var options = parts[0]
var dirs = parts[1]
```

It's better, of course, in ES6, but IMO the functional boilerplate still gets in the way:
### ES6

``` javascript
let [ options, dirs ] = _.partition(process.argv.slice(2), arg => /^-/.test(arg))
```

I was hoping this would work:
### lodash?

``` javascript
let [ options, dirs ] = _.partition(process.argv.slice(2), /^-/)
```

\- but it doesn't. Instead, the regex is treated as an object and generates a `_.matches`-style callback, which doesn't seem to be particularly useful in the case of a regex. Any interest in making it DWIM?

I know I could roll my own wrapper or use a third-party library e.g.:

``` javascript
import { matches } from 'predicates'

let [ options, dirs ] = _.partition(process.argv.slice(2), matches(/^-/))
```

\- but one of lodash's strengths is its built-in support for common patterns like this.

(While I'm at it, perhaps the `partition` documentation could mention `groupBy` e.g. "To partition a collection into more than two groups, see `groupBy`." And vice versa.)

title: applyDiffDeep?
body:
I have a situation that none of  `_.defaults`, `_.extend` and `_.assign` methods are working for me. In [Swagger Editor](https://github.com/swagger-api/swagger-editor) project I have a text editor which is constantly updating a JavaScript object. I get this JavaScript object and do some massaging to it (converting hashes to arrays and so on). Then I set this newly created object to my AngularJS scope and AngularJS will render the new preview based on the new object. It all works but because I'm setting a new object to the scope on each key press AngularJS have to re-render the entire preview pane every time. AngularJS has an awesome diff detecting mechanism but I'm not using it because every time I set a new object to the scope.

To solve this, I wrote a little function that deeply compares two objects and apply new changes to the destination object. With this, I could just apply the changes instead of re-assigning the object. 
[Here is a link to this function](https://github.com/swagger-api/swagger-editor/blob/26561263b05cc17b96c63472fb33974d0a2d1bb9/app/scripts/controllers/preview.js#L193-L268)

If it's possible to do the same operation with lodash please let me know. If this functionality is not part of lodash, I would really like to use lodash instead of writing my own function. How possible is it to have such function in lodash?

title: Chaining in per-method build
body:
When using lodash from separate packages, it's not possible to chain functions  - it's clear and obvious. But without chaining, complex operations get more and more unreadable, so usually I use helpers like [this one](https://gist.github.com/erykpiast/01514a6a4c05d8422c5a#file-patterns). I wonder if there is a place in lodash for util like that? I mean, in per-module build? I can imagine it working exactly like chaining functions in "full" library (without passing arguments to interceptor).

```
var chain = require('lodash.chain');
var assign = require('lodash.assign');
var groupBy = require('lodash.groupby');
var pick = require('lodash.pick');

chain([ 42 ])
  .thru((v) => groupBy(v))
  .thru((v) => assign(v, { "24": "24" }))
  .tap((v) => console.log(v))
  .thru((v) => pick(v, '42'))
  .value()
```

Do you find it can be useful?

title: _.zip unexpected output
body:
```
var thing = [
  ["fred", "barney", "pebbles"],
  ["38", "34", "2"],
  ["brown", "blonde", "white"]
];
thing = _.zip(thing);
console.log(JSON.stringify(thing));
```

expected:

```
[["fred","38","brown"],["barney","34","blonde"],["pebbles","2","white"]]
```

observed:

```
[[["fred","barney","pebbles"]],[["38","34","2"]],[["brown","blonde","white"]]]
```

I'll welcome any comments, including some corrections of my poor English (variable name and comment).
Thank you.

title: lazy slice after filtering may be broken
body:
`_([1, 2, 3]).filter().slice(1, 3).value();` // expected [2, 3] but actual [2]

I digged by using `git bisect` and it seems to be occured since commit 
6dfc2aca4beaabd758404b1191f7d8044c0b6c23

Sorry if I'm wrong. Thanks.

title: Using #find removes chain wrapper.
body:
``` JavaScript
_(arr).find({ id: id }) // Returns object.
_(arr).find({ id: id }).defaults({ name: 'hi' }).result('name').value(); // Breaks at defaults.
```

The example is a bit odd and perhaps this is the intended behaviour, but I think it would be nice to continue the chain using object functions after a #find.

title: Ensure something is array
body:
I think this is a feature request, but it's possible it already exists and I just can't find it.

I often find myself writing the following:

``` js
_.isArray(something) ? something : [something]
```

It would be useful if there were a function called something like ensureArray that did this:

``` js
_.ensureArray([1, 2]); // [1, 2]
_.ensureArray(1); // [1]
```

I'd be willing to write this if other people think it would be useful in the core. Also, not a fan of `ensureArray`—if anyone could think of a better name, that would be useful.

title: Publish browserified bower packages
body:
Hi!

I have been using a couple of lodash functions in frontend code.

I believe it would be great if we could pull them in as bower dependencies so that we could avoid having to bundle them with our own bower packages (avoid repetition, let bower pull the necessary lodash deps at install time).

I'm not sure about this, but I'm under the impression bower does not allow to register/publish several pkgs from the same repo.

So, have you ever looked into this and do you think it's viable to generate individual bower packages?  

Do you agree the ideal target format for each package would be bower.json + browserfied lib?

Do you think this process could be automated?

Let me know what you think, I can definitely help if needed.

title: _.rest no longer works in the same manner.
body:
Previously we could use something like

``` js
_.rest(['a','b','c'], 2)
// result is ['c']
```

but now we are seeing `['b','c']` as the result regardless of the value provided for the second parameter.

Using _.drop instead appears to work and checking the documentation it seems as though the API has changed for this method so perhaps this is by design.  It did catch us out on an application because the changelog appears to reflect the old manner in which it used to work.

From the changelog:

``` js
var array = [1, 2, 3],
_.rest(array, 2); // → [3]  
```

The second line here is not correct and is not what we see happening in version 3.1.0.  Instead we get `[2,3]`.

Can it be changed to work with the count parameter or else the changelog needs to be more explicit as this is a subtle change that you don't see unless testing for it directly.

Thanks

title: Unexpected behavior when using _.partial to build a predicate for _.filter
_.times() returns an object, not an array
body:
Look at the console:
http://jsbin.com/yesuce/1/edit?html,js,output

title: not to be bounded to window by default
body:
Hi all,

In my scenario where one of my client has different version of Lodash and my library is using different version of Lodash.

We ended up overriding our `window._`.

Is there a way to source underscore and not to be bounded to window. Instead bind to the reference provided.

Sorry if there is something already out there but I'm unaware of.

Kind regards,
Phani.

title: _.isUndefined performance
_.first(array, n) and _.last(array, n)
body:
Underscore.js supports the usage of `_.first` and `_.last` in the following manner:

``` js
_.first(array, n)
_.last(array, n)
```

These give the first and last `n` items in an array respectively.
Lodash does not appear to support this syntax. 

I am aware that Lodash offers take and takeRight, which give the same functionality. However for easy switch over from Underscore to Lodash, and to maintain Lodash as a superset of underscore, it would be best if these uses of `_.first` and `_.last` were supported.

Thanks!

title: _.find in 3.x can not cope with getters
body:
Please see this for the problem http://plnkr.co/edit/NNUlgJQYsDNCqcbR8csP?p=preview 
Method return undefined in 3.x but works fine in 2.4.1. I am using Chrome 40.0.2214.111

title: problem about the array passed to iteratee as the 3rd arg while chaining
Lodash's _.rest is different from Underscore's
body:
From what I read in the other issues, I understand that with 3.0, Lodash has dropped the Underscore replacement build for Backbone because they are compatible. However, Underscore.js 1.7 has a different `_.rest` definition (`_.rest(array, [index])`) from Lodash.js 3.1 (`_.rest(array)`).

This breaks a Backbone plugin, namely Backbone.Stickit. I cannot switch back to underscore, because I use certain features that are only available in Lodash.

I was under the impression that Lodash is providing what Underscore provides and more (and faster). I only found this issue so far, but there could be more. Could you advise me what do to in this situation?

title: Add _.pascalCase.
body:
Pascal Case is often called Upper Camel Case or Bumpy Case.

`foo_bar -> FooBar`

title: humanize for String methods?
body:
@jdalton, any consideration for adding a humanize String method?

http://api.rubyonrails.org/classes/ActiveSupport/Inflector.html#method-i-humanize

humanize(lower_case_and_underscored_word, options = {}) Link
Tweaks an attribute name for display to end users.

Specifically, humanize performs these transformations:
- Applies human inflection rules to the argument.
- Deletes leading underscores, if any.
- Removes a "_id" suffix if present.
- Replaces underscores with spaces, if any.
- Downcases all words except acronyms.
- Capitalizes the first word.
  The capitalization of the first word can be turned off by setting the :capitalize option to false (default is true).

humanize('employee_salary')              # => "Employee salary"
humanize('author_id')                    # => "Author"
humanize('author_id', capitalize: false) # => "author"
humanize('_id')                          # => "Id"
If “SSL” was defined to be an acronym:

humanize('ssl_error') # => "SSL error"

title: Add lodash.spread
body: Here is the PR to implement #756 's `_.spread`

title: Sequelizejs ResultSet cannot filter/find matches instances Using Lodash 3.x _.matches()
body:
SequelizeJS use get() method to make access by object.property translate into object.get(property)
And Because the _.matches will check the hasOwnProperty in object, SequelizeJS instances will return false and cause the filter/find result set return Array[0];

in 2.4 ->
`_.findIndex(instances, {id: 1})` => will return index of instance whose id is 1
in 3.1 ->
`_.findIndex(instances, {id: 1})` => will return -1

and we should hard code in 3.1 ->
`_.findIndex(instances, {dataValues: {id: 1}} )` => will return index of instance whose id is 1

but if some magic instance "Get" function setup, it will not be found by `{dataValues:xxx}`.
How can I deal with this problem?

title: _.compose called with no arguments returns a function that always returns undefined
body:
In version 3.1.0:

``` javascript
var a = _.compose();
a(1) // => undefined
```

In version 2.4.1:

``` javascript
var a = _.compose();
a(1) // => 1
```

title: _.where() ignores prototype members in v3.1.0...
body:
Should this work?

```
var lo = require('lodash');

function Obj(){};
Obj.prototype.is = false

lo.where([ new Obj, new Obj, new Obj ], { is: false }); // []
'is' in new Obj // true
```

result is an empty array. i would expect an array of `Obj` instances w/ length 3. this is how v2.4.1 behaved.

```
lo.where([{ is: false }, { is: false }, { is: false }], { is: false }); // [ { is: false }, { is: false }, { is: false } ]
```

returns what i expect.

if this is expected behavior, is there a more appropriate way to do what i want?

thanks in advance!

title: Observable streams
body:
I just saw this really cool talk about observable streams:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XRYN2xt11Ek

I thought it may be relevant for this project -- maybe it would be cool to incorporate these patterns at some point.
